\begin{abstract}
Quantum weak measurement, measuring some observable quantities
within the selected sub-ensemble of the entire quantum ensemble, can
produce many interesting results such as the superluminal phenomena.
An outcome of such a measurement is the weak value which has been
applied to amplify some weak signals of quantum interactions in lots
of previous references. Here, we apply the weak measurement to the
system of relativistic cold atoms. According to Einstein equivalence
principle, the internal energy of an atom will contribute its
rest-mass and consequently the external momentum of center-of-mass.
This implies a weak ``spin"-orbit coupling of atom in the free
space. After a duration of this coupling, a weak value can be
obtained by post-selecting an internal state of atoms. We show that,
such a weak value can significantly change the atoms diffraction in
the future times and consequently could help us to experimentally
measure the weak effects of special relativity.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
Almost thirty years ago, Aharonov, Albert, and Vaidman introduced
the theory of quantum weak measurement~\cite{AAV}. This measurement
have a key feature: after a weak coupling between the quantum
systems, the relevant observable quantities are measured in some
post-selected sub-ensembles. An outcome of weak measurements is the
so-called weak value $A_w$ which is a complex number and depends on
the post-selected state~\cite{Jozsa,imaginary,Anomalous}.
Physically, the pure state of a quantum system will be destroyed by
the post-selection and then becomes a mixed state which is
constituted by two pure states. Selecting out one of the pure states
to be measured, some new effects appears because the selected wave
function is very different form the original one (before the
post-selection). The post-selection is actually a physical operation
applied on the quantum state, so that the weak measurement can be
regarded as a quantum coherent operation plus a classical selection
(filtering). Hence, the weak measurement is indeed different from
the usual measurement in physics.


In the recent
refs.~\cite{Nature-wavefuction,Science-trajectory,HD,LG}, many
interesting phenomena within the weak measurements were reported,
such as spin Hall effect of light~\cite{Hall Effect}, the Cheshire
Cat~\cite{CatNJP,Cat} and the superluminal
phenomena~\cite{SuperluminalPTL, SuperluminalCherenkov,
SuperluminalBeryy,SuperluminalSteinberg}. More interestingly, lots
of studies have shown that the weak measurements can be utilize to
implement the parametric
amplifications.~\cite{Amplification0,Amplification1,Amplification2,Amplification3,
Amplification4,Amplification5,Amplification6,arXiv}. Considering an
observable quantity depends on $g|A_w|$ (with $g$ being a small
parameter), then an enlarged weak value $|A_w|$ could significantly
change the result, i.e., amplifying the weak signal of $g$ by a
clever post-selection. In experiments, most of previous refs. use
the laser interferometry to realize the desired weak
measurements~\cite{RMP}. In such an experimental system, the
necessary quantum interaction for weak value gain was realized via
the crystal-induced coupling between the polarization and momentum
of lights. Similar to the lights, the matter wave interferometry
could be also applicable for realizing the desired weak
measurements~\cite{Miao}. Recently, this has been demonstrated in
the neutron interferometry~\cite{neutron}. In such an experiment, an
external magnetic field was applied to generate the spin-orbit
coupling of neutron. Based on this coupling, the weak values were
obtained by the post-selection applied on the neutron spins.

Here, we propose using weak value to measure the relativistic
effects in atoms interferometry. According to Einstein equivalence
principle, the internal energy of an particle will contribute its
rest-mass and consequently its external momentum of center-of-mass
(c.m.). This implies a weak ``spin"-orbit coupling of
particles~\cite{Pikovski,Zych1,Zych2,Pollock,1993,1997,2004}. Such a
connection can be also obtained by the well-known time-dilation
effects of relativity which have been confirmed by the atomic clock
experiments, see, e.g., ~\cite{Hafele-Keating,Zhu2010,Mueller}.
Based on the relativistic ``spin"-orbit coupling, a weak value can
be obtained by the post-selection of atomic internal state. The
present weak value could discover new relativistic effects in atoms
interferometry. Indeed, we will show that the weak value can change
the uncertainly of spatially coherent atoms, and consequently change
significantly their diffraction in future times. Technically, this
provides an alternative approach to experimentally measure the
ultra-weak ``spin"-orbit coupling of relativistic cold atoms.

\section{Conclusion}
In this theoretical work, the quantum weak measurement is applied to
the system of relativistic cold atoms. First, we reviewed briefly
the theory of weak measurement. It is shown that the weak
measurement is indeed different from the usual quantum measurements.
A simple model is used to explain why the weak value amplification
can suppress the systematic errors of detectors. Second, we present
an approach to derive the relativistic spin-orbit coupling of a free
atom by using the Einstein energy-mass equivalence principle. After
a duration of such a coupling, a weak value is obtained by
post-selecting an atomic internal state. In experiments, we
suggested using the Raman beams and the ionization filter to realize
the desirable post-selections. Third, we have shown that the
imaginary weak value can significantly affect the atoms diffraction
after the post-selection. This result is exactly a weak measurement
effect which can not be obtained in the usual measurements.
Technically, the present weak measurement could be considered as a
potential approach to measure the ultra-weak relativistic effects of
cold atoms.
